questions.prompt: What is the difference between logical and physical addresses?
options: Logical is virtual, physical is actual RAM location
questions.explanation: Logical addresses are generated by CPU; physical addresses are actual memory locations.

questions.prompt: When does address binding at load time occur?
options: When program is loaded into memory
questions.explanation: Load-time binding generates absolute addresses when the program is loaded.
The MMU translates logical addresses to physical addresses at runtime.

questions.prompt: Dynamic loading loads all routines into memory at program start.
questions.explanation: Dynamic loading loads routines only when they are called, saving memory.

options: Moving processes between memory and disk
questions.explanation: Swapping moves entire processes between main memory and backing store.

options: Free memory scattered in small blocks
questions.explanation: External fragmentation is total free memory being fragmented into small non-contiguous blocks.

questions.prompt: Which allocation strategy finds the smallest adequate hole?
questions.explanation: Best fit searches for the smallest hole that is large enough.

options: Moving processes to create contiguous free space
questions.explanation: Compaction shuffles memory contents to place all free memory together.

questions.prompt: Compaction is always possible with any address binding.
questions.explanation: Compaction requires execution-time binding to relocate processes during execution.
Internal fragmentation is unused space within an allocated memory block.

questions.prompt: How does paging divide physical memory?
questions.explanation: Paging divides physical memory into fixed-size blocks called frames.

questions.prompt: What does a page table contain?
questions.explanation: The page table maps logical page numbers to physical frame numbers.

options: Translation lookaside buffer for fast address translation
questions.explanation: TLB is a hardware cache that stores recent page table entries for fast translation.

questions.prompt: What is the benefit of segmentation over paging?
questions.explanation: Segmentation divides memory by logical units (code, data, stack), matching program structure.
Since frames are fixed-size and any frame can hold any page, external fragmentation is eliminated.
